speaker: Jennifer Piepszak
text: Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone. Starting on page one, the firm reported net income of fourteen point three billion dollars EPS of four point five zero dollars on revenue of thirty three point one billion dollars and delivered a return on tangible common equity of twenty nine percent. Included in these results are two significant items, five point two billion of net credit reserve releases, which I'll cover in more detail shortly, and a five fifty million dollar contribution to the firm's foundation in the form of equity investments.

speaker: Jennifer Piepszak
text: Touching on a few highlights, we saw another strong quarter in CIB. In fact, net income was an all time record with IB fees up fifty seven percent year on year, reflecting continued robust activity and markets up twenty five percent year on year as the environment remained favorable in January and February, although it did start to normalize in March. In AWM, we had record net long term inflows of forty eight billion pounds this quarter. And deposits of two point two trillion pounds were up thirty six percent year on year and five percent sequentially as the Fed balance sheet continues to expand, but loan growth remains muted, up one percent year on year and two percent quarter on quarter, with the bright spots being AWM and secured lending in CIB. On to page two for more detail on our results.

speaker: Jennifer Piepszak
text: When looking at this quarter's performance, there's a lot of noise in the year on year comparisons, particularly given what happened in March of last year. And so it's important to remember a few key points here about March of twenty twenty. Effectively, investment banking activity stopped or got delayed except for investment grade debt issuance. We recorded nine hundred and fifty million of losses adjustments and other and CIB, as well as a nine hundred million dollars markdown on our bridge book. And in credit, we built six point eight billion dollars of reserves relative to this quarter's release of five point two billion So with that in mind, revenue of thirty three point one billion pounds was up four point one billion pounds or fourteen percent year on year.

speaker: Jennifer Piepszak
text: Net interest income was down one point six billion pounds or eleven percent, primarily driven by lower rates. And non interest revenue was up five point seven billion pounds or thirty nine percent. While this comparison is in part impacted by several of the items I just mentioned, in absolute terms, we saw strong fee generation across the franchise, including in investment banking, AWM and home lending, as well as a strong performance in markets. Expenses of eighteen point seven billion dollars were up twelve percent year on year on higher volume and revenue related expenses, the contribution to the foundation that I just mentioned, as well as continued investments. And credit costs were a net benefit of four point two billion dollars driven by reserve releases.

speaker: Jennifer Piepszak
text: And here it's worth noting that charge offs were down about four hundred million dollars year on year or twenty eight percent and continue to trend near historical lows. Turning to page three for more detail on our reserves. We released approximately five point two billion dollars of reserves this quarter as recent economic data has been consistently positive, indicating that the recovery may be accelerating faster than we would have thought just a few months ago. Starting with consumer, in card, we released three point five billion dollars as the employment picture has continued to improve, the round three stimulus has provided another level of support, and early stage delinquencies remain very low. And in home lending, we released six twenty five million dollars primarily driven by continued improvement in HPI expectations and to a lesser extent portfolio runoff.

speaker: Jennifer Piepszak
text: And then in wholesale, we released approximately seven hundred million While a strong recovery seems in motion, we're also prepared for more adverse outcomes given remaining uncertainties around the impact of new virus strains and the health of the underlying labor markets. So for now, we remain cautious and are still weighted to our downside scenarios. And at about twenty six billion, we're reserved at approximately seven billion above the current base case. However, it's worth noting that even in a more normalized environment, we wouldn't expect to be one hundred percent weighted to the base case as we'll always have some weighting on alternative scenarios. Now moving to balance sheet and capital on page four.

speaker: Jennifer Piepszak
text: We ended the quarter with a CET1 ratio of thirteen point one percent, flat versus the prior quarter, as net growth and retained earnings was offset by lower AOCI and higher RWA. Perhaps the more interesting ratio right now is SLR, which is at five point five percent excluding the temporary relief that just expired. As we've said all along, we were never going to rely on short term temporary relief as a long term planning matter, and this is evidenced by actions we've taken. We've already engaged with our wholesale deposit clients to explore solutions, and we issued one point five billion dollars of preferred stock in the first quarter. Having said that, it's worth reinforcing a few points here.

speaker: Jennifer Piepszak
text: First, it's important to remember that the SLR is a leverage based requirement, not a risk based requirement. The growth in bank leverage has been driven by deposits and therefore cannot be cured by reducing lending. In fact, the opposite would be true. If we had more loan growth, it would help because it would absorb excess risk based capital. The issue is that we've had muted loan demand to date, and even if it starts to pick up, it's hard to envision that organic loan growth could keep pace with further QE, and therefore, we expect this leverage issue to persist for some time.

speaker: Jennifer Piepszak
text: And finally, when a bank is leverage constrained, this lowers the marginal value of any deposit, regardless if it is wholesale or retail, operational or nonoperational, and regulators should consider whether requiring banks to hold additional capital for further deposit growth is the right outcome. As we told you last quarter, we have levers to manage SLR and we will. However, raising capital against deposits and or turning away deposits are unnatural actions for banks and cannot be good for the system in the long run. And then just to wrap up on capital regarding distributions, the limitations were extended another quarter. So based on our income, that corresponds to buyback capacity of about seven point four billion dollars in the second quarter after paying our zero nine zero dollars dividend.

speaker: Jennifer Piepszak
text: Given the preferreds we plan to issue and the work underway around excess client deposits, while of course this could become more challenging, we believe that we should be able to buy back most, if not all, of that capacity. speaker: Jennifer Piepszak
text: Client investment assets were up forty four percent, driven by market appreciation and positive net flows across our adviser and digital channels. speaker: Jennifer Piepszak
text: That said, we are seeing strong momentum in T and E with spend up more than fifty percent in March compared to February and similar growth across DX Loyalty and Ultimate Rewards travel bookings.
